segments.text: Now, after you go back to Cambridge, then, you stay there for a while.
And what next?
Well, I stayed at Cambridge until I retired.
And then every summer, I came here to La Jolla for two to three months.
I was a professor here and a professor in Cambridge, which is probably contrary to the regulations of both universities.
And then when I retired from Cambridge, I moved here.
Partly because I couldn't work in Cambridge, I couldn't get a job, and partly for tax reasons.
What you said just now, a few thoughts on what you said just before we started recording.
You said that people didn't always realize that the old fashioned views of history about the influence of individuals,
still had, in fact, an element of truth in them.
The pendulum had swung a long way in the other direction under Marxist influence.
It was believed that the economic environment and the needs of the ruling class were the predominant thing, almost to the exclusion of the individual.
And the pendulum is now swinging back, and I think most people would probably agree that

Marxist ideas of the influence of the ruling class on what actually gets done and the importance of the economics of the thing are one side of the picture but of course if you now say how does this thing work itself out in practice why are things done in one place and not another then you do have the influence of the people and this is very important because it's
It's relevant to education.
I mean, what kind of people are you trying to educate?

The idea of education now is to a great extent to push a lot of information in, test to see it, look through a hole and test to see it's still there, and then give people a degree quickly before it spills out.
And I think what you said,
and a sense in which there are certain kinds of people who do in fact get things done.
And this is not necessarily an entirely intellectual question.
It's a question of character, frame of mind, even of the way you're brought up.
I mean, Rutherford, for instance, was, as I said last time, I think, looked at himself as a farmer's boy.
In a sense, what one might call a liberated person.
That's to say, he knew what he wanted.
He thought he ought to have it.
He had a conviction that what he was doing was worthwhile and the right thing.
And this is very striking in Ewing.
The certainty that what he wanted to do was what the Lord would have done.
And I think this is extremely important.
The development of
a self-confidence in persons in positions of leadership.

If they just go along doing what they did for their PhD, you see almost the majority of scientists do something for their PhD and go on doing the same thing and don't sort of get out of it and are continually on the defensive about this matter still being important.
I found a whole group of people in Yale recently
doing what I did for my PhD on electron scattering.
And the subject didn't seem to change very much.
The techniques were a bit better.
But how anyone, a young man, could go into this, I find it difficult to believe.
Anyway, I'm sure this is mostly my ignorance.
The group is probably doing something useful.
But the idea, when I say liberated, I mean this, that you see what you want to do, you consider what you need to do it,
not what you think you can get.
That if you have some great scheme for going to Mars, you shouldn't say to yourself, I can't do this, I shan't be able to get the money.
You should say, now what does this cost?
Have a realistic idea of what is needed to do it, and then if you really think it's worthwhile, go and try and find someone who will make it possible to do it.
And I think the thing that modern education lacks to some extent
Is the developing in people a self-confidence?
It's all concerned not with the old-fashioned character development, but with the acquisition of knowledge.
I mean, there's so much more knowledge to acquire now.
This is obviously a line of least resistance.
And I've always tried with graduate students to get them to want to do something.
to come to me and say, what I'd like to do is this.
And I say, well, then, all right, let's do it.
You get out a plan for doing it.
How big a ship do you need?
How many people do you need?
What do you need to do?
And then find the money.
And sometimes these PhD problems can cost hundreds of thousands of dollars.
And one should try and make young people believe
Not that one is very short of money and has to be very careful, you know, like many professors are, but to make them believe there's lots of money in the world, let's go out and get it.
I think there is an important way in which the director of a research group can do this sort of semi-psychological education.
It's a kind of character development, a view of the world,
And of course undergraduates like this too.
If you're lecturing to undergraduates, they love these stories about blowing up ships.
And unfortunately we broke the ship in the middle of this kind of thing.
The rather cheerful attitude to life that you can't make omelettes without breaking eggs.
Someone told me the other day that it was Lenin who first said, you can't make onwards without breaking eggs.
Is this really true?
I don't know.
I've never heard that accredited to him.
I don't think it's true, but I found it somewhere the other day.
I think it can't be true.
It's a phrase I've always known.
Me too, and it doesn't sound as something Lenin would say.
It doesn't sound like that, no.
He said it apropos shooting people.
Okay, that's right.
I mean, bloody murderer and wanted an excuse for shooting people.
He probably said you can't make forms unless you kill Kulaks.
That would sound more sense to me.
Well, now, when you retire then from Cambridge, you come here permanently to work, partially because you can work here and...
I'm on a year-to-year contract, yeah?
And I'm getting paid six months of the year, and the other six months I make my living by my wits.

And this in Cambridge, I mean, I could go on, I suppose, doing my own work in Cambridge, but here I can do some teaching, have some graduate students, and the discontinuity on retiring is much less here than it is in Cambridge.
Cambridge is frightened of making any distinction between people, so they have a fixed retiring age cut, and it would be quite foreign to their feelings to...
say Mr. A can stay on for another year and Mr. B can't.
On the same grounds, they pay all professors equally.
Okay.
What about the tax structure in England?
I don't want to talk about the tax structure in England.
I will just say this, that my pension from Cambridge is a lump sum of money, and I have to invest that to get a pension.
After the first thousand pounds, this is taxed at 50%, and the tax goes up to 98%.
And I'm not going to live in a country that does that to them.

Well, the reason I was asking is we have been fortunate in this country to be able to attract a goodly number of people from Britain and England in particular because the tax structure has been so... Well, of course, now, just at this moment, of course, you could attract an indefinite number of people.
But, of course, you can't get them residence visas.
Yeah, right.
You can't get them labor permits.
That's right.
Actually, you can usually do it a year at a time.
You get them an H1 visa a year at a time.
It's just taken me 16 months to get a residence visa.
You've no idea what the documentation is like.
Everyone's very charming and nice about it, but clearly the whole process is so complicated as to constitute an intelligence case.
Now...
You have continued your work on here, then, oceanography.
Now, I have a series of questions, if you don't mind, I'd like to ask you that are sort of what-if questions.
All right?
If you had to name what you consider your greatest single scientific contribution, and I realize that's a terrible question, what would you name?
Oh, dear, oh, dear, oh, dear.
I think I know what other people would say.
They would probably say the heat flow work.
Absolutely.
My own feeling is that it is to have provided the atmosphere and the opportunity for the group that nailed down continental drift.
I made contributions to it myself, particularly the taking seriously Wegener's idea of the fits of the continents in the past.
At the same time, I forgot to mention it,
At the same time as the other work was going on, I was working with two graduate students on seeing whether North America and Greenland would fit into Europe and South America into Africa.
And we found the fit was incomparably better than anyone had expected.
Also, I think, the reason I hesitated was that I was, in fact, the first person to do seismic shooting at sea
with the instruments not on the bottom, which is a very necessary discovery.

It would have been discovered almost at once by other people, but I was in fact the first to do it, because it's very difficult to put instruments on the bottom of the deep sea, and rather easy to put them near the surface.
Well, I mean, it's an unanswerable question, it doesn't make much sense really, but I'd have thought the building up
of this group in Cambridge that made this great contribution to the modern ideas.
Teaching at Scripps, how do you find American students?
Well, I have great fun teaching at Scripps.
I enjoy it enormously.
I teach a first year course on the earth to non-scientists.
So we've got all kinds of people.
As a matter of fact, I've noticed as the years go by that we get a larger and larger proportion of scientists in it.
They sort of creep in out of the woodwork.
It's directed, in principle, at non-scientists who want to do one course in science.
And these students I find absolutely charming, most delightful people, extremely appreciative, very nice to me personally, always come and talk to me afterwards.
very restrained in expressing their troubles if they don't get good grades and so on.
Really very nice people.
Their main trouble is they can't write at all.
I mean, they're hardly literate, which is very surprising for arts people.
I talked about this last time.
I would say the outstanding defect of American education at the moment is not to teach writing.
People can read, but they can't write.
They aren't, of course, very good at speaking either.
The standard of public speaking in America is not high, with a few well-known exceptions.
But on the whole, if you put a student on to make an after-dinner speech or something, it's pretty lamentable.
Well, the other side I know is the graduate students, of course.
The graduate students are extremely well-informed, I think much better informed,
than our English students.
They know more.
Partly because they have to do courses as graduate students.
You see, we have a three-year undergraduate course, so the transition from school to a graduate student is three years.
And when they become graduate students, there are courses they can go to, but they don't go to them, and they don't have to go to them, and they don't have any exam.
What they have to do is do a piece of original work, write a thesis on it,
and pass an oral exam on the thesis and on the general subject in which it falls.
And I described my own oral exam last time.
The idea of the general subject in which it falls is fairly wide.
But they don't have any more examinations on courses.
So that I think your students, when they've got their PhDs, know more than us do.
I think
This amount of formal teaching is a little inhibiting of the sort of freedom I was talking about.
The sort of optimism and belief that you can do anything, which I learned partly from Rutherford and partly from the war.
I mean, the war is a thing which had an enormous and I think almost entirely favorable influence on scientists, and which the present generation has missed, of course.
I mean a whole generation.
It was a thing in which it gave you confidence because what you were doing was regarded as important and not as an eccentric hobby.
And I think part of this drift towards applied and relevant projects is an effort to find a way of working
which will be acceptable to the society, in which you will be regarded as a valuable and useful member of society.
And I think this is a good thing.
I think the ivory tower, things like particle physics, if I were a young man I wouldn't go into particle physics.
Dreadful subject.
Very high prestige in scientific circles, but not outside.
There's a very, many scientists who have a very restricted idea of what is interesting, of course.
I mean, questions like the safety of nuclear power stations, disposal of nuclear waste.
A serious interest in these matters is almost not science.
Do you believe then, is it fair to say, that a good oceanographer is also a generalist in science?
Oh, you've got to be a generalist.
You asked me yesterday whether I thought people were more specialized, and I said no, I thought they had to be much less specialized, because the subjects are much less clearly demarcated.
I mean, if we take oceanography, for example,
This whole subject, which I've spent my life developing largely, of the study of the bottom of the ocean, marine geology, this has connections in all directions.
It's obviously got connections with geology.
It's got connections with the traditional oceanography.
I mean, the sense of sedimentation and all the techniques of dealing with things covered by several miles of water.
And it's got connections with physics.
Now we've got global theories.
We have to develop mechanisms.
What is it that moves the continents?
All these kinds of things.
So you're connected with everything from the most difficult theoretical physics to orthodox geology.
And the things have become unstuck.
That when I was young, geology was a complete thing with a ring around it.
You could say what was geology.
It was in practice defined as something we did with a hammer and a microscope.
and now it's become connected with everything else.
Okay, now what I wanted to do was use that as a lead-in question.
I note that in your, well, in what has been written about you, you list yourself as, in effect, belonging to no political party.
I just don't say anything about it.
Okay, that's fine.
I wondered if you thought, as a scientist who is a generalist,
that you ought to express opinions on things like nuclear waste.
I'm extremely interested in politics, in fact.
But no one who's looking for an American visa is going to say what their politics are, whatever they are.
My politics are, in fact, to the right of center Republican in American terms, right-wing conservative in English terms.
I was, for a long while,
very willing to put up with Nixon on the grounds that I preferred a knave to a fool.
He seemed to me, he turned out eventually to be both a knave and a fool.
But for a while, I thought he was just a knave, which seemed to me relatively harmless.
But anyway, I would say, if Ford can be said to have a position, I thought that was about fine.
But of course, he is rather extremely non-intellectual.
I'm certainly to the right of Rockefeller and certainly to the left of Bellwater, this sort of position.
Well, now, I've taken great interest in a tremendous amount of time and trouble over questions connected with disarmament.
I've been a British delegate at Geneva.
I was a member of the experts conference in 58 at Geneva.
I've been a member of the Pogwash affair for many, many years.
all kinds of committees connected with disarmament agreements with the Russians.
I've also been closely connected with defense.
I think I mentioned last time, I was chairman of the Anglo-American Ballistic Missiles Committee, which was for a while a body of some significance.
And so I have spent quite a lot of time on this.
I'm not, however, a joiner.
I generally don't sign things.
You know, there are always protests about
someone having shot someone in Uganda, or someone having failed to let a Jew out of Russia, or those endless protest things.
And if you once start signing these, you get yourself typed in the public mind, and if you aren't extremely careful, you'll find you've in effect joined some crypto-communist movement.
A lot of these things are simply concealed lawsuits of the Communist Party.
And so I've systematically refused to sign any of these appeals that are published in the newspapers and so on.
But I have belonged to official bodies for many years.
I was a member of the Foreign Office Committee on Disarmament and all these.
I was a member of the Institute of Strategic Studies for a good many years, so I got bored with it.
I'm not, in the ordinary sense, politically active, but I've
I'm really an , you might say.

That's to say, if I'd taken a little more trouble about it and been a little more interested, I would probably have been like Jerry Wiesner or Solly Zuckerman and been advisor to some president or prime minister or something and sort of sat in a back room and been generally regarded as a nefarious influence.
But I never had the time, really, to devote to that.
I have spent a lot of time talking to politicians and advising them.
Now, I had wanted to ask you some things about your international commitments.
Really, I want to ask you three things about them.
First of all, are you optimistic in terms of future development of the seas about international cooperation in oceanography?
Oh, dear.
Of course,
you've got two conflicting tendencies.
On the whole, the developed countries are interested in collaborating in a tremendous task, which is clearly a global task, and can't be done locally.
And so far as the Japanese, the Americans, the Canadians, Western Europe, British, there is no problem.
And the Russians, there is no problem.
The troubles come

from the undeveloped countries who for easily understandable reasons regard anything which is done by the developed countries as being an attempt to steal something from them and therefore their tendency is to get control of as much as possible and keep the developed countries out till such a time as they've developed their own understanding and technology and this is the back
of the Conference on the Law of the Sea.
It's been promoted by the undeveloped countries very largely.
The Americans, the British, and the Russians would much rather the whole thing didn't happen, because we're doing quite well as it is.
But all these other countries are trying to produce restrictive arrangements, and I think it's difficult to judge how it comes out.
I find it difficult to believe that the developed countries will give in
If necessary, they won't sign the treaty.
You see, if you had to get permission from the nearest country every time you operated at sea, it would be impossible to operate.
I mean, you'd have to say exactly what you were going to do months and months and months beforehand.
You'd often get refused at the last minute if you just kill oceanography as a science.
And it may happen that the governments of the United States and Western Europe decide to throw the scientists to the wolves in return for some other concession.
But I don't think they will.
I've spent a lot of time talking to the Foreign Office people about this.
and I know something about the corresponding negotiations in this country and Canada.
Canada has behaved very badly and is tending to join the undeveloped countries over this for reasons that are very difficult to tell.
I've had endless correspondence with the Canadians about this, and I just do not know why they're being so foolish.
Now, that really, in fact, answers my second question, which had to do with the 200-mile limit.
What sort of effect did you think that would have on the country?
Well, it depends, you see, what you mean by the limit.
I think it is inevitable that we are going to have a 200 mile limit.
I don't see that there's any way out of this.
I think the conference won't agree, and we'll have unilateral declarations of 200 mile limits.
And I don't see as much anyone can do about it.
We've got to live with it.
This largely closes work on the continental shelves.
And I can understand the desire of, well, of course,
so far as mineral resources is concerned, is not very different from the 58 Treaty, the Treaty on the Continental Shelf.
In any case, the nearest land has control of the exploitation of mineral resources.
Well, they're clearly also going to take fishing rights after those distances, I think, and I fear they're going to take a thing which is no justification at all in international law,
That is control of scientific investigations within these units.

This, at the moment, on the continental shelf in Western Europe, whatever the international law may be, we have an arrangement by which the countries on both sides of the Peace of Sea Concern give notice.
And this works quite well.
They just give notice, the Foreign Office circulates the plans, and anyone who wishes to object can object.
The thing looked like becoming a nuisance at one time.
They were circulating them and requiring you to say you didn't object.
I persuaded them that they only needed a reply who did object.
And this ensures practically that no one ever does.
And this is working very well.
But I think it's going to be impossible to do work of any sort within 200 miles of any undeveloped country.
Well, we may just have to put up with this.
And I think in some cases, such as Argentina, one can reach agreements with them, bilateral agreements for doing things.
In the case of Chile, at the moment you could.
Three or four years ago you couldn't.
They'll ask for, in the African case, they'll ask for concessions, money, something of the kind.
But, of course, it still leaves most of the deep sea free for investigation.
What I'm terrified of is an agreement about investigation in the deep sea.
What sort of an agreement?
Well, an agreement, I imagine it would be an agreement by which one, there was an international body run by the UN from whom we had to get permission, which I think would be intolerable.
Well, now then, the third of these questions in this series, if I may.
Do you foresee, in effect, more cooperation between industrial countries in broad-scale oceanographic ventures or less?
Well, I think so far as the government and academic community is concerned, I should have thought the collaboration is already very extensive and will continue.
French project with a considerable British input as well.
And almost all oceanographic expeditions are to some extent international.
I mean here in Scripps they borrowed a Canadian ship recently and there are all kinds of very free and easy interchange and the deep sea drilling project is now an international project.
That was partly, of course, to ease the effects of restrictions.
It's easier to get permission for an international project over an area claimed by some other state than it is for a national project.
So I'd have thought that, partly because things are expensive, partly because it is in its nature international, that the very satisfactory international collaboration would go on.
If you start to develop
commercial things on the ocean floor, then of course there are rather different considerations.
If it's very expensive, then they may be glad of collaboration from firms in various parts of the world.
If you feel you can finance it yourself, you'll obviously do it yourself.
The military things would only be collaboration between allies.
I mean, I think it's unlikely we'll collaborate with the Russians over military things.
So it is one of my views that we should encourage

um relations of a technical kind connected with military affairs with the russians because the most dangerous thing is misapprehensions and if you wish for example to have means of detection of the motion of ships over the ocean then there's something to be said for having a joint a joint arrangement with the russians so you both have the same information you can always add your own domestic system as well if you want to but i i'm not sure that the
absolute separation of the two opposing sides in their technical measures is sensible
